titleStmt.title: New propositions from His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, agreed upon by the Generall, Lieutenant-Generall, Colonels, Lieutenant-Colonels, Majors, and Captaines, under his Excellencies command, at a late Councell of Warre. Concerning, the brotherly meetings of Independents, and divers other well-affected people of this kingdome. With their desires to both Houses of Parliament concerning the same. Also, some particulars concerning the Booke of Common-Prayer. And the last propositions from the souldiery to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, concerning a great member of this kingdome. Published for generall satisfaction.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Army. Council.

titleStmt.title: New propositions from His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, agreed upon by the Generall, Lieutenant-Generall, Colonels, Lieutenant-Colonels, Majors, and Captaines, under his Excellencies command, at a late Councell of Warre. Concerning, the brotherly meetings of Independents, and divers other well-affected people of this kingdome. With their desires to both Houses of Parliament concerning the same. Also, some particulars concerning the Booke of Common-Prayer. And the last propositions from the souldiery to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, concerning a great member of this kingdome. titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Army. Council.
Fairfax, Thomas Fairfax, Baron, 1612-1671.

notesStmt.note: A collection of three documents: "The copy of a letter from Wooburn Lodge in Bedfordshire, concerning the Kings Majesty, &c."; "A copy of the propositions and desires of the souldiery, concerning Col. Gen. Poyntz presented to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax"; and "Another paper from his Excellency to the Lord Mayor and Common-Councel of the City of London", which is dated and signed at end: Reading Iuly 19. 1647. By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax and the Counsell of Warre. Signed Io. Rushworth Secret.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NEW PROPOSITIONS From His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, AGREED Upon by the Generall, Lieutenant-Generall, Colenels Lieutenant-Colenels, Majors, and Captaines, under his Excellencies Command at a late Councell of Warre.
CONCERNING, The Brotherly Meetings of Independents, and divers other well-affected People of this Kingdome. With their De≈øires to both Hou≈øes of Parliament concerning the ≈øame.
ALSO, Some particulars concerning the Booke of Common-Prayer. And the la≈øt Propo≈øitions from the Souldiery to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, concerning a great Member of this Kingdome.
Imprinted at London for T: Deane, Anno 1647.

div.head: THE COPY OF A LETTER FROM Wooburn Lodge in Bedford≈øhire, concerning the Kings Maje≈øty, &c.
div.p:
THe particulars which I have to repre≈øent unto you at this pre≈øent, are things very remarkable and of great con≈øequence, being of ripene≈ø≈øe and maturity, both for the view of your Metropolis, and the whole Kingdome al≈øo: Therefore, for ≈øati≈øfaction
of your ≈øelves, and the re≈øt of your Fellow Commoners, I ≈øhall here communicate unto you, a Copy of ≈øome further Propo≈øals, agreed upon by the Generall, and his Councell of War, concerning all ≈øuch per≈øons as are impri≈øoned under pretence of Conventicles, as likewi≈øe touching the book of Common-Prayer, together with ≈øeverall other papers here enclo≈øed; all wdich, I ≈øhall here give you in order, as followeth.

div.head: I
div.p:
WHereas divers per≈øons really affected to the weale and peace of this Kingdom, are now impri≈øoned & grievou≈øly vexed, by force or pretence of ≈øeverall Statutes (e≈øpecially intended) again≈øt all tho≈øe who repaire not to ≈øome Church or Chappell to heare the Booke of Common-prayer, or again≈øt tho≈øe who are popi≈øh Recu≈øants, and by their not going to Church might be di≈øcovered: and again≈øt the≈øe who ≈øhould hold any Conventicles of Meetings, to plot and con≈øpire ≈øome mi≈øchiefe to the State. Now fora≈ømuch as the Parliament hath declared again≈øt the Booke of Common-prayer, and that the ≈øaid Act again≈øt
the Conventicles was not intended again≈øt people meeting only for Religious Exerci≈øes: it is therefore de≈øired, That all per≈øons proceeded again≈øt upon any Statute or Act what≈øoever may bee forthwith di≈øcharged from their impri≈øonments, indictments, or any other mole≈øtation what≈øoever, by vertue of the fore-mentioned Statutes, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øuch per≈øons ≈øhall be proved either popi≈øh Recu≈øants (and that by ≈øome other way then by their not coming to Church) or to have in ≈øuch private Meetings as afore≈øaid ≈øome perjurious de≈øign, con≈øpiracy, and practice again≈øt the State. Therefore, for a more effectuall cour≈øe herein, it is de≈øired, That the Parliament would bee plea≈øed to give Orders for the acquitting of all per≈øons as afore≈øaid, by vertue, or under pretence of the ≈øaid Statutes, otherwi≈øe then as before excepted.

p.hi: A≈ø≈øented to by the Generall, and the re≈øt of the Officers under his Excellencies command.

div.head: A Copy of the Propo≈øitions and De≈øires of the Souldiery, concerning Col. Gen. Poyntz pre≈øented to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax.
div.p: 1. That your Excellency would be plea≈øed ≈øeriou≈øly to ponder the ≈øadne≈ø≈øe of our conditioq in beins de≈øtitute of a Commander in chief, of known integrity, and that accordily your Excellency would be plea≈øed to helpe us in this our great nece≈ø≈øitp

2. That your Excellency would be plea≈øed to further what≈øoever may couduce to our future ≈øafety, for we conceive our ≈øelves very neer to de≈øtruction, when the Enemies of our well-being have the command over us, and would willingly make us acce≈ø≈øary to out owu thraldome.

3. That your Excellency would be plea≈øed to cau≈øe this cdarge to be pro≈øecuted again≈øt him by a Councell of Warre of Army more immediatly under your Excellencies command, many officers here being acc≈ø≈øeary with him in the ≈øame undertaking.

4. The≈øe things being performed, we humbly de≈øire your Excellencies ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider our former engagements with you in former ≈øervice, and to take ≈øuch cou≈øe for our future ≈øupply with pay as we may not lye langui≈øhing, when our Enemies are in pro≈øperity.

argument.p: This is a perfect Copy of the four Heads or Propo≈øitions pre≈øented to his Excellency from the Northern Party,

div.head: Another Paper from his Excellency to the Lord Mayor and Common-Councel of the City of London.
div.p: IN the carrying on of the great bu≈øine≈ø≈øes of the Kingdome towards a generall and happy ≈øettlement, it hath been a fixed principle with us to make it our fir≈øt endeavour with the Parliament, that all things which threaten an engagement of the Kingdome in a ≈øecond Warre, might be removed before we could have a confident expectation of a good i≈ø≈øue; which upon a Treaty with their Commi≈ø≈øioners, which cour≈øe of ours, although it might have ≈øome appearance of delay: yet by men that are zealous of the Kingdoms good (we hope) no endeavour will be judged unnece≈ø≈øary, that may ≈øecure the Kingdome from the danger of any new imbroylements.

We are now come thus far, that the mo≈øt materiall particulars which we have in preparation to propo≈øe, for the generall ≈øettlement of the affaires of the Kingdome, have been communicated to the Parliaments Commi≈ø≈øioners; and we hope they are ≈øatisfied, that they contain in them thing; tending to a generall good, and to lay an hopefull Foundation for common Right, and Freedom, to the people of this Land for future; and for a la≈øting peace among≈øt us. But before we can ≈øecurely intend and without interruption apply our ≈øelves unto the proceedings and di≈øpatch of the Treaty, thereupon we have delivered into the hands of their Commi≈ø≈øioners, the Paper which con≈øi≈øts of three particulars, in the la≈øt whereof (which is the Militia of the City) you being mo≈øt immediatly concerned, to the end you may ≈øee wee would ask nothing which relates to you, without giving you a ju≈øt account thereof, and all po≈ø≈øible ≈øatisfaction therein; we have al≈øo given a Copy thereof to your Commi≈ø≈øioners, to be here with ≈øent unto you. We ≈øhould not de≈øire this, ort any thing el≈øe of that nature, were we not per≈øwaded, thas what we de≈øire is ≈øea≈øonable, and for yours and the Kingdome good and quiet. And we ≈øhould willingly have been ≈øilen- (as to this:) but con≈øidering the ju≈øt jealou≈øies which lye at
gain≈øt ≈øome per≈øons, now authorized in the exerci≈øe of th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ power among≈øt you, and tho≈øe attempts which have beene made by ≈øome, who would have engaged your City, to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Warre, had not your Lord≈øhips and the Court of Aldermen and Common-Councell, by your wi≈ødome prevented it, by getting tho≈øe Votes which were pa≈ø≈øed by the Militia, made Null; We cannot in a ca≈øe of this importance but deale freely with you, in de≈øiring your concurrence with ours to the Parliament; that the Militia may be changed into tho≈øe hands, out of which it was taken, of who≈øe care and fidelity to the Publick, there hath been ≈øo long and large Experience as few ages have paralell'd. And if the intere≈øt we have ≈øo long fought for be ≈øtill the ≈øame, let it not ≈øeem ≈øtrange that we de≈øire both of the Parliament and City, that tho≈øe may be in places of ≈øuch a Tru≈øt, who have given the be≈øt proofe of their courage and con≈øtancy in pro≈øecution of the ≈øame.

Having thus far declared our ≈øelves with all freedome and clearne≈ø≈øe to you, as we do not your good acceptance of your intention therein, ≈øo we de≈øire your forwa dne≈ø≈øe in a work ≈øo much tending to mu uall confidence; and to prevent the de≈øignes of any who would be glad to put ob≈øtructions in the way to a happy conclu≈øion, and envy nothing more then the continuance of a right under≈øtanding betweene you and us.

closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax and the Coun≈øell of Warre. Signed Io. Ru≈øhworth Secret'
